page.title: 01Landscape and Buildings
page.content: St.Erth village is set in a rural landscape which is dominated by dairy and arable and some sheep farming. The area reaches Hayle on the Atlantic coast in the North East,to North West lies Trencrom Hill (a granite outcrop now owned by the National Trust).To the South the area is little populated except for a number of farms. A mile away from the village,and lying adjacent to the main A30 road that runs through the county of Cornwall,is St Erth station. The village itself has a church originally built in the 14th. or 15th.Centuries.The Parish, Church and village of St Erth all received their name from the Irishman Ercus who lived from 424 to 515AD,he came across the Channel to establish the church.
